1483549784510124032.text: In total, these infrastructure investments will improve the quality of life in our communities, while creating good-paying jobs, boosting our economy, and addressing the climate crisis.

1483549780596772866.text: To address air pollution that disproportionately impacts our most vulnerable communities, the law invests $7.5 billion in clean school buses and ferries and $7.5 billion for electric vehicle charging infrastructure.

1483549778566737921.text: The law also delivers clean and safe drinking water to families across the country and invests $55 billion in water infrastructure, including over $23 billion for drinking and wastewater infrastructure and $15 billion for the replacement of lead pipes.

1483549776775835648.text: The #BipartisanInfrastructureLaw ensures every American has access to reliable and affordable high-speed internet. The new law invests $65 billion in broadband infrastructure, which is all the more critical especially now during the pandemic.

$110B for roads and bridges

1476703921070510088.text: The #WomenVetsTaskForce honors Staff Sergeant Julia Kabance for her remarkable contributions and distinguished service to our country. https://t.co/nINRp2T0C6

1476703918360907776.text: For her years of distinguished service to our nation, she received the Good Conduct Medal, the World War II Victory Medal, the American Campaign Medal, and the DAR Distinguished Citizen Medal. https://t.co/kmNJ5Rvl8u

1476703915680829446.text: After retiring in 1972, Kabance moved to St. Mary’s, Kansas, where she spent her time volunteering for her church and was an active and proud member of the American Legion We-Ta-Se Post 410.

1476703913411710990.text: She also volunteered at the VA Medical Center in Topeka for over 17 years serving her fellow veterans. https://t.co/PK071hVacB

1476703911922733061.text: Following her service, she moved home to care for her ailing mother. She was then employed by the U.S. Air Force in Topeka, Kansas and she later worked in accounting for the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers. https://t.co/TqPzm4SATw

1476703910756716564.text: During World War II, Kabance was stationed at McChord Air Force Base and Fort Leavenworth, where she provided administrative support and spent time as a driver for the U.S. Army. After the war, due to the loss of her hearing, Kabance was honorably discharged as a staff sergeant.

1476703909611638785.text: Julia attended basic training at Fort Des Moines Cavalry Post, where she stayed in barracks that had been converted from horse stables.

1476703907833286674.text: Julia attended Kewanka grade school and Holton High School, then Haskell Indian Nations University for a year before enlisting in the Women’s Army Auxiliary Corps in 1943. https://t.co/ioj44W2xVS

1476703905757106177.text: As we continue the #WomensVetsTaskForce series celebrating the contributions of #womenvets, we commemorate the life and service of Julia Kabance, who was the oldest World War II woman veteran and member of the Prairie Band Potawatomi Nation when she passed on November 16, 2021. https://t.co/nltU2pzZjv

1390016642890051588.text: Despite her injuries, she obtained a medical waiver to stay in the Illinois Army National Guard until her retirement as Lieutenant Colonel in 2014. Lt. Col. Duckworth earned the Purple Heart for her meritorious service and today, she represents Illinois in the U.S. Senate.

1390016641774333959.text: She was among the first of Army women to fly combat missions during Operation Iraqi Freedom. In November 2004, her UH-60 Black Hawk Helicopter was hit by an RPG and she lost her legs and partial use of her right arm.

1390016639299686407.text: The daughter of a Chinese Thai mother and an American father, Sen. Duckworth joined the Army ROTC in 1992. She then joined the National Guard and trained as a helicopter pilot until she was called to active duty and sent to Iraq in 2004.

1375291804493344773.text: Sgt. Maj. Canley represents the very best of our men and women in our Armed Forces and exemplifies the spirit of all those who have answered the call to serve our country in uniform.

1375291803147010048.text: My office pursued the case and, in 2018, Sgt. Maj. Canley was awarded the Medal of Honor for his valor and decisive action in protecting his fellow brothers-in-arms.

1375291801758654469.text: In 2014, I was contacted by one of Sgt. Maj. Canley’s fellow servicemen who inquired about upgrading his award to the Medal of Honor – the highest military award given by the U.S. government.

1375291800248741899.text: This advanced the war strategically and saved many American lives. For his extraordinary heroism, Sgt. Maj. Canley received the Navy Cross, as well as two Bronze Stars and a Purple Heart.

1375291798340308992.text: In 1968, during the Battle of Hue, his commanding officer was shot and gravely wounded. Then-Gunnery Sergeant Canley took immediate command of his company and directed several counter attacks over many long days under heavy fire.

1375291796310269956.text: On #MedalOfHonorDay, let us recognize the extraordinary service of Oxnard resident & Medal of Honor recipient Sergeant Major John Canley, whose brave actions during the Vietnam War saved the lives of many of his fellow Marines and played a critical role during the Tet Offensive. https://t.co/KYJZdav5u9

1375241761778364420.text: After the war, Dr. Walker was awarded the Medal of Honor by President Andrew Johnson for her meritorious service in caring for sick and wounded soldiers, both in the field and hospitals. This #WomensHistoryMonth, we honor Dr. Mary Edwards Walker for her service.

1375241761153413123.text: After being held as a prisoner of war by Confederate troops, she became assistant surgeon of the Ohio 52nd Infantry.

1375241760410984449.text: Dr. Walker was not allowed to serve as a medical officer during the Civil War because she was a woman. However, she volunteered as an unpaid surgeon until her request to practice was granted in 1863 in Ohio – becoming the first woman surgeon in the U.S. Army.

1375241757839921152.text: On this #MedalofHonorDay, the #WomensVetsTaskForce recognizes Dr. Mary Edwards Walker, who was a surgeon, abolitionist, women’s rights activist, and is still the only woman to receive the Medal of Honor. https://t.co/FfoU5CZxEp
